displayed_text: Patient: ‘Cuz see, I don’t know how I got careless, and, and, but I keep a lot of stuff in my pockets. When it happened before where I was. Doctor: Okay. Patient: So, I did like I said, did like I told her and she been like I told you (Miss F_ and I said) Doctor: Mm, hmm. Patient: And call me. Let my daughter know and let me know.” ‘Cuz I’m sure I’m gonna press charges. I swear to God, I’m gonna press charges. Doctor: Yeah. Okay. So, what happened then? Did they give you the medication? Patient: Huh? Doctor: Last time, what happened? Did they give you the medicine? Patient: No, I, I, I just, the last one you gave me is the one that I lost. But I picked up the one that you gave me before then. Doctor: Before? Patient: Yes. Doctor: Okay. So, you picked it up on August thirtieth? Patient: The, no, the, I think

Patient: Okay, I’m good with that. That sounds good. Okay? Doctor: It’s okay. Patient: I happy with it. Doctor: Great. You guys had a lot of good questions today. Patient: We learned to ask. You got to speak up. That’s right. Doctor: You got to advocate for yourself. Right? That’s absolutely the one thing. So, very good. Patient: So, that’s good news that we can travel. I like being able to see the grandkids you know. Doctor: Yeah, yeah, and they’ll tell you exactly when and how long, you know, the kids, exposure, all of that he will explain. But we will start with giving you a side effects sheet and then I’ll have J____ come in and just tell J____, our nurse, Patient: Yeah, right. Doctor: about what to expect and how she’s going to do the prior authorization and then well we’ll kick you to the curb. Okay? Patient: Okay. Sounds good. Doctor: We’ll get out next one for I think it’s two months from now maybe for the shot. Family Member: Yeah. It will be the time for the Lupron.

Family Member: Okay. Patient: And the way… Doctor: Okay. Family Member: You better do it. You better do it B____. You better do it. Patient: The way everybody’s been explaining it to me is that too many people can’t be writing you pain med prescriptions. Doctor: Correct. Well, and we only saw you to just check in. Patient: Okay. Doctor: If we got audited, it would be well, you’re not even taking care of him so what are you writing all this stuff for… Patient: Right. Doctor: …but you’re gonna be under our care for the study. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So we’ll just assume that at this point otherwise you’re driving here, you’re driving there, it makes no sense.

Family Member: That’s an immunotherapy? Doctor: No that’s a it’s a PARP inhibitor which is known to produce really good responses with this medication, with the BRCA mutant prostate cancer. Okay? Patient: Including BRCA2? Doctor: Yeah. Family Member: That’s the one we had the article about. Doctor: Yeah, so I think you know that is sort of the somewhat well paved route. Okay because it’s known that the response rates are likely to be pretty good. The other way is -- Patient: Would I continue on the Xtandi in that case or not? Family Member: Okay but she said there’s a third choice. Patient: Just a second, just a second, just a second I’m digesting this. Family Member: Sorry. Patient: Thank you. Ah… Doctor: I know it’s a lot of things to go through.

Healthcare Professional: Do we have to take for that too? Patient: So you want me to have her set up for one week from today? Doctor: Yeah, next week. Patient: Okay, alrighty. Doctor: Yep, yep and if I don’t need you to come we’ll call you and let you know… Patient: Okay. Doctor: …that you know, everything’s fine you don’t need to come or whatever. Patient: Alright then no problem. Doctor: Alright?

Patient: Mm, hmm. Doctor: And, if they all do well and nothing happens to them, then we treat three more men at a higher dose level, and if nothing happens to them, we go to a higher dose level. Um. Patient: With different people? Doctor: Different people. You know? I would have to check. Again, some of the things we’d have to clarify. Uh, it is – if you’re, let’s say you’re --come in at the second dose level, and you are on it and it, it’s not, the cancer’s not getting worse. Uh, does it make sense to go to the higher dose. Patient: Mhm. Doctor: That those men are safe. Or, the fact that your cancer’s not getting worse, why would we change the dose? Patient: Right. Doctor: So, a lot of times, they don’t let us move up. Sometimes they let us move up if the next guys have tolerated it well. Patient: And showed improvement or something like that? Doctor: Um, uh, yeah, that would be tough. And if they were benefiting and you weren’t, maybe higher dose – I don’t know what the rules are. Patient: Yeah. Doctor: But, oftentimes they don’t let us increase the dose.

Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …I don’t think it’ll happen. The radiology guys will go over that. Um from a research standpoint, we hang onto your stuff. If any point in time you’re like (pfft) Patient: Mhmm. Doctor: …Otherwise we literally try to maximize as much information as possible from your stupid cancer. Patient: Well as I as I said, if… Doctor: Yeah. Patient: …if, if it’s anywhere, if it’s, if it’s the same people that did the port if it’s people that as are as competent as the people that did the port, I have no problem with it at all. Doctor: Yeah. They do it all day long which is terrific. Patient: Because it was not, I mean it wss - it was a not, it was a total non-event. In and out, it was a total non-event. Doctor: Yeah. I agree. That’s that’s wonderful. Okay okay, sit tight here. I’m gonna have M____ come in. Patient: Alright. Doctor: She’s gonna harass you anyways. And then afterwards if we have other questions we’ll we’ll chit-chat some more. Patient: I would appreciate it if you would have your nutrition people take a look.

Patient: And my hydration has always been plus a little bit in there. So I think that that might be a temporary ah thing like for the last two days. Doctor: Mhmm. Okay. Patient: It could have been – and my schedule is pretty weird. Family Member: Oh yes. Doctor: Is it easing up so you can take some fluids or am I giving you fluids today? (pause) Family Member: Oh boy. Patient: No it’s – no… …it’s easy, it’s easy enough yeah… Family Member: If he thinks of it he can get it anywhere he is. Patient: Because I drink water. I like water. Family Member: Yes. Doctor: You’re gonna have to make it an effort then get in to see the nephrology folks… Patient: Okay. Family Member: Okay.

Patient: It’s alright. (laughs) Doctor: Fifty-nine. And generally men under sixty have a recurrence I mean are able to have a sexual function even without medication ultimately. Patient: Um hmm. Doctor: So I suspect that you’ll probably be there. Patient: Okay. Doctor: Alright? It’s still early. Patient: Okay, I know. I know. Doctor: Hang in there. Patient: I try to keep that… Doctor: Okay. Patient: …here and you know I try to stay, stay busy to keep my mind away from you know how you automatically get you know. Doctor: Sure, right.

Patient: Yeah. Doctor: Then you’ve got the Xarelto you take once a day? Patient: Yep. Doctor: Okay. Did I miss anything? Family Member: No. Patient: No. Doctor: No other vitamins? No other herbs? Family Member: Uh-uh. Doctor: Nothing else to move your bowels? Patient: No. Doctor: Did you already get your shot today? You got to go up and get it? Family Member: Yes. He’s gotten it.

Thank you for your valuable contributions to our study! Our goal is to understand how doctors can communicate better with patients by looking at different perceptions of the doctors’ qualities. Understanding your personal experiences with the medical system will help us to contextualize your responses. We invite you to share insights by answering the following questions. Your answers to these questions are strictly confidential and anonymous.

About how long has it been since you las.Within the past year (anytime less than: About how long has it been since you last saw a doctor or other health professional about your health?:::Within the past year (anytime less than 12 months ago)

During the past 12 months, not counting.2 times: During the past 12 months, not counting times you went to an emergency room, how many times did you go to a doctor, nurse, or other health professional to get care for yourself?:::2 times

Sometimes doctors care more about what i.neutral: Sometimes doctors care more about what is convenient for them than about their patients' medical needs.:::neutral

Doctors are extremely thorough and caref.neutral: Doctors are extremely thorough and careful.:::neutral

You completely trust doctors' decisions.agree: You completely trust doctors' decisions about which medical treatments are best.:::agree

A doctor would never mislead you about a.disagree: A doctor would never mislead you about anything.:::disagree

All in all, you trust doctors completely.agree: All in all, you trust doctors completely.:::agree

People of my ethnic group receive the sa.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group receive the same medical care from doctors and healthcare workers as people from other groups::: strongly disagree

People of my ethnic group are treated th.strongly disagree: People of my ethnic group are treated the same as people of other groups by doctors and healthcare workers::: strongly disagree

Doctors have the best interests of peopl.neutral: Doctors have the best interests of people of my ethnic group in mind:::neutral

Which of the following best describe you.Unemployed for less than 1 year: Which of the following best describe your current occupational status? Mark all that apply.:::Unemployed for less than 1 year

What is the highest grade or level of s.Postgraduate: What is the highest grade or level of schooling you completed?:::Postgraduate

Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or.No, not Hispanic or Latino: Are you of Hispanic or Latino origin or descent?:::No, not Hispanic or Latino

What race or races do you consider yours.Black or African American: What race or races do you consider yourself to be?:::Black or African American

displayed_text: Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Particularly because you’re not really symptomatic right now, I don’t think, and, you know, the, the benefits of both, uh, are about the same. Uh, so, and the side effects of chemotherapy are just, you know-? Patient: Um hum. Doctor: More to deal with. So, so if we were going to choose, uh, I would probably choose one of the hormone pills as the next thing to do. Patient: Um hum. Doctor: Uh, the clinical trials that we have, uh, at this point, uh, whether you’re ready to do another clinical trial after having just been on one. (Laughter) Doctor: Uh, the one upside of clinical trials is, you might of noticed, is you get a research nurse who kind of is like your concierge who runs everything for you. Patient: Right. Right. Doctor: And it’s good for you and for me. Patient: Right. Doctor: Uh, we do have, uh, uh, the one drug called, Xtandi. We have two clinical trials, and those trials are both trying to make the drug work better by combining it with other, other drugs- Patient: Hum. Doctor: That in some ways compliment the hormone therapy. Uh, both of the two trials that we have, though, do require a biopsy, and I don’t know, I’ll have to go back and look to see if they’d allow a bone biopsy.

Patient: Yes, understand. Doctor: So that’s important that we get the pulmonary evaluation, what they’re thinking. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: It’s likely that we probably need new pictures to sort of see what your liver is doing. And I think it’s time in some ways because you know the Enzalutamide is not controlling your PSA, and you’re ARV7 positive it’s likely that if we got more pictures we would see more cancer. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: I need to know what’s going on with your lungs because some of the treatments that we would talk about have toxicity to the lungs as one of the main side effects. Patient: Okay. Doctor: So I think he’s mentioned in his note a standard option for you go to would be to chemotherapy. So chemotherapy in someone like you after hormones haven’t worked well enough or long enough; Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: chemotherapy shrinks the PSA for a while, shrinks the tumor for a while in about forty/fifty percent of people. So almost half the people get some benefit from chemotherapy. Family Member: Mm, hmm. Doctor: We usually know after three or four cycles as to whether or not it’s gonna help, and we keep going. Family Member: Mm, hmm.

Patient: What’s the Doctor: -that it may happen right after the first – Patient: What’s the, yeah, how about enlightening me on how much time are we talking about before - Doctor: So, so my plan right now is to give you about two or three courses and do a repeat scan. Patient: That’s uh - Doctor: So one time every three weeks is called one cycle. So today if you get it, that’s your first cycle of treatment. Next treatment will be due in three weeks from today. Patient: Oh it’s every three weeks. Doctor: Correct. Patient: So I would take two or three treatments? Doctor: Uh, I’m thinking right now three, three, then we do a repeat scan. And if it’s working, if things are shrinking in there, we keep going. Family Member: Uh hum. Doctor: On an average people get six. The typical sort of maximum if people are having a tremendous benefit and doing fine with it, you know I can go up to ten. But, but we’ll see how it goes. Patient: Well, I mean (chuckles)

Patient: I -- I’m preparing for that. Doctor: He’s prepared. It’s what he loves to do. Patient: Yeah. I’m – Doctor: But I think her point is you just do it within reason. If you ride twelve hours a day, you’re not drinkin’ fluids, you’re not takin’ your stool softeners, you don’t want to mess yourself up – Patient: I’m --- just listen. Listen to this, doc. Doctor: That’s hard. That’s all. Patient: Listen to this. Listen to this. Doctor: Okay. Patient: I’m gonna do all that. Doctor: Yeah. Patient: Okay? Because I’m wearin’ the, the pad now anyway. Doctor: Okay.

Patient: Okay. Doctor: That one doesn’t care. Patient: Right. If everything looks good, I’d like to come back on the nineteenth. Doctor: Right. So, if we communicate by MyChart or I_ and I will communicate with you about stopping the drugs, if you decide, but I want you to take a look at it Patient: Okay. Doctor: More, more. Patient: Yeah, perfect. Doctor: And again, most of the time, a clock starts ticking the day you take your last dose. Patient: Okay. And so, I, do -- Doctor: So, when you guys are driving back and you say, you know, “I’m gonna stop.” You just stop. You know, if you need to get more of the TGF-A, I’ll let I_ know. Patient: Now, this one here. It looks like, um, the only thing that I’d have to stop would be the Lilly drug, right? Doctor: Ummm. Any Enzalutamide, I believe. You’d stay on your hormone shot.
